reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hull BreacH is a sci-fi first person survival game. You found yourself on a ship all alone and have to survive basically. Reminded me a lot of the movie The Martian to be honest. The game is still in Early Access so they’re improving it all the time.

Graphics :

The graphics are average, nothing fancy the FPS is good and game runs smooth.

Sound :

There isn’t any music or voice acting in the game other than the one line at the start of the game. Only your footsteps and the breaches’ alarms going off is all you’ll hear. I guess it adds to the lonely atmosphere.

Gameplay :

The gameplay involves you running around the ship fixing breaches and in the process keeping up your basic needs such as hunger, thirst, morale, oxygen etc. It’s a good concept and the atmosphere of the game really gives that all alone in space scary feeling.

You have to survive the days, as a day goes past you get new breaches such as fires, and atmosphere leaks, you have to fix those, you can find them by looking for alarm cues and sort of like a waypoint which tell you where the breach/broken thing is. After fixing you then have to concentrate on keeping yourself healthy by going to the medical rooms and getting in the med pod to heal your diseases, they can also be healed with medicine . Once you’re done with fixing breaches and eating food water, there’s basically nothing much to do after other than wait for the 24 hours to be over and to do all that all over again. Surviving isn’t hard at all because there’s plenty of supplies all over the ship.

One annoying thing in the game is the lack of a minimap, I know there are plenty of maps all over the ship which tell you where you are currently but a minimap is always helpful especially if the rooms and the ship looks the same everywhere you go.

Though there is many bugs but that’s expected as the game is still in Early Access and many bugs should be fixed by the developers. The most annoying bug I ran across was when I adjusted FOV to be a bit wider FOV kept increasing automatically and the viewmodel and the onscreen menus became so small that they were unreadable. So I had to keep adjusting the FOV to be able to read the menu not to mention the wider FOV makes everything look weird even at 80 FOV. Yea, imagine doing that everytime you want to look in your inventory and/or check your health status.


Graphics: 6/10
Sound: 2/10
Gameplay: 6/10
Overall: 5.5/10

Conclusion :

The game is not bad but it can be improved a lot and more interesting mechanics can be added. Bug fixes should be fixed and some sort of story should also be added. If you like survival games you should give it a try otherwise I’d say wait for the game to come out of Early Access and/or sale on the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EARLY ACCESS review, 6/1/16

Short Version: A lonely, barren, poorly rendered spaceship crumbles around you as you futilely try to patch up your broken little world just enough to survive the inevitable decay, prolonging your lonely, barren, poorly rendered existence for one more day.  First-Person-Survival that might work as an art piece for the meta 'feels'... but not so much as a full fledged game.

Drift into Eternity is a survival game that puts you in the shoes of the only wo/man alive on a spaceship that is falling apart a little more every day.  You must scavenge supplies from all around the ship to fix up the hull breaches, fires, and broken life support systems that crop up in greater numbers every day as you try to survive in hopes of a rescue that may never come.

The game's hook is interesting, and it certainly has potential to become a game worthy of playing, but in its current early access state it unfortunately lacks the content a $15+ game is usually expected to deliver.

The graphics aren't great, and even the current bland-ish visuals caused numerous hitches on my machine. The audio is equally mediocre at this point, consisting of a lone voice telling you about objects when you press the tutorial button, the constant rumbling of your spaceship, and the ubiquitous wailing of sirens as things break down around you.

The gameplay itself just doesn't have enough substance at the moment to retain interest.  You open endless containers (which usually don't resemble containers or have any highlights or animations to mark them as such), 'take all' of the endless parts, then hunt down an endless number of broken/smoking/flaming things and right click to fix.  Meanwhile you must eat/drink/self-medicate just enough to stay alive....endlessly.  This repetition definitely adds to the atmosphere of desperate futility the game seems to be going for, but doesn't provide much in the way of entertainment value (which ironically, is one of the things you have to do to survive in the game - keep your character entertained).

All in all, Drift Into Eternity has an interesting concept that could be neat to try, but probably not at the current point in development or at the current price.  However, the developers do seem to be very active, patching things frequently along with providing a clearly labeled timeline of what they hope to achieve in the next six months  - and visibly active development is a definite positive for an Early Access title.  So, if the concept of the game intrigues you, you could consider supporting the development of the game and hoping for the best... but if you're searching for a survival game to fully enjoy now, you may want to keep looking.


Received a free copy for testing/reviewing purposes.  This review is part of the Steamified Community Review program. For similar reviews and fantastic giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

Review written on Saturday, May 7th, 2016

Review
Your spaceship crashed on an unknown planet.
You're alone and you need to survive. The enemy? The environment and your body.
You need to keep the spaceship in good conditions, you need to keep your body healthy.
Don't forget to entertain yourself!

In the beginning you have nothing.  You need to collect resources like food, repair items, etc. At the start of the day you'll get a report of the problems on your spaceship. That will be your tasks for the day. The repair items will be used to fix the spaceship: broken objects and rooms on fire. You also need to be careful with poisoned food - it will make you sick and you can die.

There is no minimap, but a few maps on the wall. It can become disorientating.

The game has great potential.

It's not an easy game. It doesn't hold your hand.

Rating:
7.5/10

Pros:
Great atmosphere.
There's no music in game, this helps build a feeling of isolation and loneliness
It's not easy.
Interesting mechanics.
Cons:  Once you fix the spaceship there's nothing else to do, but collect resources and wait for the end of the day.
The game crashed two times when starting a new day.
For similar reviews and great giveaways please visit Steamified[www.steamified.com]

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Drift Into Eternity:
~~~~~~~~~~~~

What a ride, you might say! You are the sole survivor of a crash-landing on an unknown planet. The good news – well, you are alive! The question is, for how long? Your spaceship has sustained a lot of damage and as days goes by, more breakages occur!

Drift Into Eternity is a First Person survival game set in a fallen spaceship. At the start, you will wake up in your personal cabin and learn the basic functions of the game. Then you will be advised on how many breaks the vessel suffered on a daily basis via the logbook. You might have some specific equipment to fix or even to extinguish fires in several rooms. You will be able to identify where the breaks are located by the flashing red lights and the sound of the alarm in front of the room where the repairs are needed. Green smoke is also a sign of damage, so make sure you go through the area with a fine comb.

A small point I forgot to mention is that you start with absolutely nothing on you, and not only do you have to repair the ship but you have to make sure you find enough food and water to survive another day in this grim environment! Be aware of the rotten food which can cause you illness and make sure that your state of mind is at its optimum by reading comic books, magazines or listening to music. Try to stock as many useful items as possible in your inventory, so when you come across equipment to repair you hopefully have the right component to fix it.

The vessel has two decks that you can explore and you will have to find a teleporter to move from one deck to the other. Remember to read your log book carefully as damage can occur on both decks on a same day. One thing that I miss in this game is a mini-map; sure you have maps of the ship on the walls here and there, but I find it to be not so helpful.
The graphics are average but the game runs very well. I like the Keyboard rendition before starting the game but there is nothing else in regards to the sounds apart from the sound effects, which are footsteps and alarms.

Positives:
~~~~~~~~

-	Great music intro
-	Well-designed decks
-	Plenty of items to find and use
-	Achievements

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	No mini-map
-	Graphics need to be polished (Early access)
-	No trading cards

This game is currently in early access and shows good potential. I look forward to see more updates.

7/10

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!
